SEARCH
Package io.github.ulalax.zmq.core

Class LibZmq

java.lang.Object
io.github.ulalax.zmq.core.LibZmq
public final class LibZmq extends Object
Low-level bindings to libzmq using Java Foreign Function & Memory (FFM) API.

This class provides direct access to all native ZeroMQ (libzmq) functions through Java's FFM API introduced in Java 21. It serves as the foundation layer for higher-level ZeroMQ abstractions.

Usage Example:


 // Create context
 MemorySegment context = LibZmq.ctxNew();

 // Create socket
 MemorySegment socket = LibZmq.socket(context, ZmqConstants.ZMQ_REP);
 LibZmq.bind(socket, "tcp://*:5555");

 // Use socket...

 // Cleanup
 LibZmq.close(socket);
 LibZmq.ctxTerm(context);

Thread Safety:

These functions match libzmq's thread-safety guarantees:

  • Context operations (ctxNew, ctxTerm, etc.) are thread-safe
  • Socket operations are NOT thread-safe - a socket must not be used by multiple threads simultaneously
  • Message operations are NOT thread-safe - messages are not thread-safe

Error Handling:

Most functions return -1 on error and set errno. Use errno() and strerror(int) to retrieve error information, or use ZmqException.throwIfError(int) for automatic exception throwing.

Since:
1.0.0
See Also:

  • Method Details

    • errno

      public static int errno()
      Retrieves the last error number set by a ZeroMQ function.

      This function corresponds to zmq_errno() in the C API. The error number can be used to determine what went wrong with the last operation.

      Returns:
      the error number (errno) from the last ZeroMQ operation
      See Also:
      • strerror(int)

    • strerror

      public static String strerror(int errnum)
      Converts an error number to a human-readable error message string.

      This function corresponds to zmq_strerror() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      errnum - the error number to convert
      Returns:
      a string describing the error
      See Also:
      • errno()

    • version

      public static int[] version()
      Reports the version of the ZeroMQ library.

      This function corresponds to zmq_version() in the C API. The version is returned as a three-element array containing the major, minor, and patch version numbers.

      Returns:
      an array of three integers [major, minor, patch] representing the library version

    • ctxNew

      public static MemorySegment ctxNew()
      Creates a new ZeroMQ context.

      A context is the container for all sockets in a single process. It manages I/O threads and other resources. You must create exactly one context per process.

      This function corresponds to zmq_ctx_new() in the C API.

      Returns:
      a pointer to the newly created context, or NULL on error
      See Also:
      • ctxTerm(MemorySegment)
      • ctxShutdown(MemorySegment)

    • ctxTerm

      public static int ctxTerm(MemorySegment context)
      Terminates a ZeroMQ context.

      This function destroys the context and closes all sockets that might still be associated with it. It will block until all pending operations complete and all sockets are closed.

      This function corresponds to zmq_ctx_term() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      context - the context to terminate
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ctxNew()
      • ctxShutdown(MemorySegment)

    • ctxShutdown

      public static int ctxShutdown(MemorySegment context)
      Shuts down a ZeroMQ context without destroying it.

      This function causes all blocking operations currently in progress on sockets associated with the context to return immediately with an error code of ETERM. Unlike ctxTerm(MemorySegment), this does not destroy the context.

      This function corresponds to zmq_ctx_shutdown() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      context - the context to shutdown
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ctxTerm(MemorySegment)

    • ctxSet

      public static int ctxSet(MemorySegment context, int option, int optval)
      Sets a context option.

      This function sets the specified option for the given context. Available options include ZMQ_IO_THREADS, ZMQ_MAX_SOCKETS, etc.

      This function corresponds to zmq_ctx_set() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      context - the context to modify
      option - the option to set (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_IO_THREADS)
      optval - the value to set for the option
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ctxGet(MemorySegment, int)
      • ZmqConstants

    • ctxGet

      public static int ctxGet(MemorySegment context, int option)
      Gets a context option value.

      This function retrieves the value of the specified option for the given context.

      This function corresponds to zmq_ctx_get() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      context - the context to query
      option - the option to retrieve (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_IO_THREADS)
      Returns:
      the option value on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ctxSet(MemorySegment, int, int)
      • ZmqConstants

    • socket

      public static MemorySegment socket(MemorySegment context, int type)
      Creates a ZeroMQ socket within the specified context.

      This function creates a socket of the specified type and associates it with the context. The socket type determines the semantics of communication.

      This function corresponds to zmq_socket() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      context - the context in which to create the socket
      type - the socket type (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_REQ, ZmqConstants.ZMQ_REP)
      Returns:
      a pointer to the newly created socket, or NULL on error
      See Also:
      • close(MemorySegment)
      • ZmqConstants

    • close

      public static int close(MemorySegment socket)
      Closes a ZeroMQ socket.

      This function destroys the socket and releases all resources associated with it. Any outstanding messages will be discarded unless the linger period is set.

      This function corresponds to zmq_close() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to close
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • socket(MemorySegment, int)

    • bind

      public static int bind(MemorySegment socket, String addr)
      Binds a socket to a local endpoint and accepts incoming connections.

      This function binds the socket to a local endpoint and then accepts incoming connections on that endpoint. The endpoint is a string consisting of a transport protocol followed by an address.

      This function corresponds to zmq_bind() in the C API.

      Example endpoints:

      • tcp://*:5555 - TCP on all interfaces, port 5555
      • ipc:///tmp/feeds/0 - Unix domain socket
      • inproc://my-endpoint - In-process transport
      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to bind
      addr - the endpoint address string
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • connect(MemorySegment, String)
      • unbind(MemorySegment, String)

    • connect

      public static int connect(MemorySegment socket, String addr)
      Connects a socket to an endpoint and accepts outgoing connections.

      This function connects the socket to an endpoint and then accepts outgoing connections to that endpoint.

      This function corresponds to zmq_connect() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to connect
      addr - the endpoint address string
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • bind(MemorySegment, String)
      • disconnect(MemorySegment, String)

    • unbind

      public static int unbind(MemorySegment socket, String addr)
      Unbinds a socket from an endpoint.

      This function unbinds the socket from the specified endpoint. The endpoint must have been previously bound using bind(MemorySegment, String).

      This function corresponds to zmq_unbind() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to unbind
      addr - the endpoint address string to unbind from
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • bind(MemorySegment, String)

    • disconnect

      public static int disconnect(MemorySegment socket, String addr)
      Disconnects a socket from an endpoint.

      This function disconnects the socket from the specified endpoint. The endpoint must have been previously connected using connect(MemorySegment, String).

      This function corresponds to zmq_disconnect() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to disconnect
      addr - the endpoint address string to disconnect from
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • connect(MemorySegment, String)

    • setSockOpt

      public static int setSockOpt(MemorySegment socket, int option, MemorySegment optval, long optvallen)
      Sets a socket option.

      This function sets the specified option on the given socket. Options control various aspects of socket behavior such as I/O threads, message patterns, and transport protocols.

      This function corresponds to zmq_setsockopt() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to modify
      option - the option to set (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_SUBSCRIBE)
      optval - a pointer to the option value
      optvallen - the size of the option value in bytes
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • getSockOpt(MemorySegment, int, MemorySegment, MemorySegment)
      • ZmqConstants

    • getSockOpt

      public static int getSockOpt(MemorySegment socket, int option, MemorySegment optval, MemorySegment optvallen)
      Gets a socket option value.

      This function retrieves the value of the specified option for the given socket.

      This function corresponds to zmq_getsockopt() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to query
      option - the option to retrieve
      optval - a pointer to store the option value
      optvallen - a pointer to the size of the option value buffer (input/output)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • setSockOpt(MemorySegment, int, MemorySegment, long)
      • ZmqConstants

    • send

      public static int send(MemorySegment socket, MemorySegment buf, long len, int flags)
      Sends a message on a socket.

      This function queues a message to be sent on the socket. The message is not necessarily sent immediately. Use flags to control blocking behavior and multi-part messages.

      This function corresponds to zmq_send() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to send on
      buf - a pointer to the message data
      len - the length of the message in bytes
      flags - flags to control send behavior (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_DONTWAIT, ZmqConstants.ZMQ_SNDMORE)
      Returns:
      the number of bytes sent on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • recv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, long, int)
      • msgSend(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int)

    • recv

      public static int recv(MemorySegment socket, MemorySegment buf, long len, int flags)
      Receives a message from a socket.

      This function receives a message from the socket and stores it in the buffer. Use flags to control blocking behavior.

      This function corresponds to zmq_recv() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to receive from
      buf - a pointer to store the received message data
      len - the size of the buffer in bytes
      flags - flags to control receive behavior (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_DONTWAIT)
      Returns:
      the number of bytes received on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • send(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, long, int)
      • msgRecv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int)

    • socketMonitor

      public static int socketMonitor(MemorySegment socket, String addr, int events)
      Spawns a socket monitor to track socket events.

      This function spawns a PAIR socket that publishes socket state changes (events) over the inproc:// transport to the specified endpoint.

      This function corresponds to zmq_socket_monitor() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      socket - the socket to monitor
      addr - the endpoint address to publish events on (inproc:// protocol), or null to disable monitoring
      events - a bitmask of events to monitor (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_EVENT_ALL)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ZmqConstants

    • msgInit

      public static int msgInit(MemorySegment msg)
      Initializes an empty ZeroMQ message.

      This function initializes a message object with zero length. Use this before calling msgRecv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int).

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_init() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message structure to initialize
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgClose(MemorySegment)
      • msgInitSize(MemorySegment, long)

    • msgInitSize

      public static int msgInitSize(MemorySegment msg, long size)
      Initializes a ZeroMQ message of a specified size.

      This function initializes a message object to hold a message of the specified size. The message content is uninitialized.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_init_size() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message structure to initialize
      size - the size of the message in bytes
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgClose(MemorySegment)
      • msgInit(MemorySegment)

    • msgInitData

      public static int msgInitData(MemorySegment msg, MemorySegment data, long size, MemorySegment ffn, MemorySegment hint)
      Initializes a ZeroMQ message from a pre-allocated buffer.

      This function initializes a message object to reference existing data. A free function can be specified to deallocate the data when the message is released.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_init_data() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message structure to initialize
      data - a pointer to the message data
      size - the size of the message data in bytes
      ffn - a pointer to the free function (or NULL)
      hint - a hint passed to the free function (or NULL)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgClose(MemorySegment)

    • msgSend

      public static int msgSend(MemorySegment msg, MemorySegment socket, int flags)
      Sends a message on a socket (zero-copy).

      This function queues the message to be sent on the socket. After a successful call, the message is transferred to ZeroMQ and the message structure is reinitialized to an empty message. This is a zero-copy operation.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_send() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message to send
      socket - the socket to send on
      flags - flags to control send behavior (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_DONTWAIT, ZmqConstants.ZMQ_SNDMORE)
      Returns:
      the number of bytes sent on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgRecv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int)
      • send(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, long, int)

    • msgRecv

      public static int msgRecv(MemorySegment msg, MemorySegment socket, int flags)
      Receives a message from a socket (zero-copy).

      This function receives a message from the socket and stores it in the message structure. Any content previously stored in the message is released. This is a zero-copy operation.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_recv() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message structure to receive into
      socket - the socket to receive from
      flags - flags to control receive behavior (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_DONTWAIT)
      Returns:
      the number of bytes received on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgSend(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int)
      • recv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, long, int)

    • msgClose

      public static int msgClose(MemorySegment msg)
      Releases a ZeroMQ message.

      This function releases the message and frees all resources associated with it. After calling this function, the message structure should be reinitialized before being used again.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_close() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message to release
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgInit(MemorySegment)

    • msgMove

      public static int msgMove(MemorySegment dest, MemorySegment src)
      Moves the content of one message to another (destructive).

      This function moves the content of the source message to the destination message. After the operation, the source message is reinitialized to an empty message. No actual data copying occurs - this is a pointer operation.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_move() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      dest - a pointer to the destination message
      src - a pointer to the source message
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgCopy(MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • msgCopy

      public static int msgCopy(MemorySegment dest, MemorySegment src)
      Copies the content of one message to another.

      This function copies the content of the source message to the destination message. The copy is shallow - both messages reference the same underlying data with reference counting.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_copy() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      dest - a pointer to the destination message
      src - a pointer to the source message
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgMove(MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • msgData

      public static MemorySegment msgData(MemorySegment msg)
      Returns a pointer to the message data.

      This function returns a pointer to the message content. The returned pointer is valid only as long as the message is valid and has not been closed or modified.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_data() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      Returns:
      a pointer to the message data
      See Also:
      • msgSize(MemorySegment)

    • msgSize

      public static long msgSize(MemorySegment msg)
      Returns the size of the message data in bytes.

      This function returns the size of the message content in bytes.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_size() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      Returns:
      the size of the message in bytes
      See Also:
      • msgData(MemorySegment)

    • msgMore

      public static int msgMore(MemorySegment msg)
      Checks if more message parts are to follow.

      This function indicates whether there are more message parts to follow after receiving a message part. It is used for receiving multi-part messages.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_more() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      Returns:
      1 if more message parts follow, 0 if this is the last part
      See Also:
      • msgRecv(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, int)

    • msgGet

      public static int msgGet(MemorySegment msg, int property)
      Gets a message property value.

      This function retrieves the value of the specified message metadata property.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_get() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      property - the property to retrieve (e.g., ZmqConstants.ZMQ_MORE)
      Returns:
      the property value on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgSet(MemorySegment, int, int)

    • msgSet

      public static int msgSet(MemorySegment msg, int property, int optval)
      Sets a message property value.

      This function sets the specified message metadata property to the given value.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_set() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      property - the property to set
      optval - the value to set for the property
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • msgGet(MemorySegment, int)

    • msgGets

      public static String msgGets(MemorySegment msg, String property)
      Gets a message metadata property as a string.

      This function retrieves the value of the specified message metadata property as a string.

      This function corresponds to zmq_msg_gets() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      msg - a pointer to the message
      property - the name of the property to retrieve
      Returns:
      the property value as a string, or null if the property does not exist
      See Also:
      • msgGet(MemorySegment, int)

    • poll

      public static int poll(MemorySegment items, int nitems, long timeout)
      Polls for events on multiple ZeroMQ sockets.

      This function allows an application to multiplex input/output events over a set of sockets. It blocks until one or more of the requested events occurs, or until the timeout expires.

      This function corresponds to zmq_poll() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      items - a pointer to an array of zmq_pollitem_t structures
      nitems - the number of items in the poll items array
      timeout - the timeout in milliseconds (-1 for infinite, 0 for non-blocking)
      Returns:
      the number of items with events on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • ZmqStructs.getPollItemLayout()

    • proxy

      public static int proxy(MemorySegment frontend, MemorySegment backend, MemorySegment capture)
      Starts a built-in ZeroMQ proxy device.

      This function connects a frontend socket to a backend socket, forwarding messages between them. Optionally, all messages can be captured by a third socket. This function blocks indefinitely.

      This function corresponds to zmq_proxy() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      frontend - the frontend socket
      backend - the backend socket
      capture - the capture socket (or NULL to disable capturing)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error (typically only returns on error)
      See Also:
      • proxySteerable(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • proxySteerable

      public static int proxySteerable(MemorySegment frontend, MemorySegment backend, MemorySegment capture, MemorySegment control)
      Starts a built-in ZeroMQ proxy device with control flow.

      This function is similar to proxy(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, MemorySegment), but adds a control socket that allows the proxy to be paused, resumed, or terminated.

      This function corresponds to zmq_proxy_steerable() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      frontend - the frontend socket
      backend - the backend socket
      capture - the capture socket (or NULL to disable capturing)
      control - the control socket to receive commands (PAUSE, RESUME, TERMINATE)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • proxy(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • has

      public static int has(String capability)
      Checks if a specific capability is available in the ZeroMQ library.

      This function checks whether the library was compiled with support for a specific capability such as "ipc", "pgm", "tipc", "norm", "curve", "gssapi", or "draft".

      This function corresponds to zmq_has() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      capability - the name of the capability to check (e.g., "ipc", "curve")
      Returns:
      1 if the capability is available, 0 if not available

    • z85Encode

      public static MemorySegment z85Encode(MemorySegment dest, MemorySegment data, long size)
      Encodes binary data into Z85 printable text.

      This function encodes a binary key as Z85 printable text. The size of the binary data must be divisible by 4. The output buffer must be at least (size * 5/4) + 1 bytes.

      This function corresponds to zmq_z85_encode() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      dest - a pointer to the destination buffer for the encoded string
      data - a pointer to the binary data to encode
      size - the size of the binary data in bytes (must be divisible by 4)
      Returns:
      a pointer to the destination buffer on success, NULL on error
      See Also:
      • z85Decode(MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • z85Decode

      public static MemorySegment z85Decode(MemorySegment dest, MemorySegment str)
      Decodes Z85 printable text into binary data.

      This function decodes a Z85 encoded string into binary data. The output buffer must be at least (strlen(str) * 4/5) bytes.

      This function corresponds to zmq_z85_decode() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      dest - a pointer to the destination buffer for the decoded binary data
      str - a pointer to the Z85 encoded string
      Returns:
      a pointer to the destination buffer on success, NULL on error
      See Also:
      • z85Encode(MemorySegment, MemorySegment, long)

    • curveKeypair

      public static int curveKeypair(MemorySegment z85PublicKey, MemorySegment z85SecretKey)
      Generates a new CURVE key pair.

      This function generates a new random CURVE key pair, consisting of a public key and a secret key. Both keys are Z85-encoded strings of 40 characters plus null terminator. The buffers must be at least 41 bytes each.

      This function corresponds to zmq_curve_keypair() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      z85PublicKey - a pointer to a buffer to store the Z85-encoded public key (41 bytes)
      z85SecretKey - a pointer to a buffer to store the Z85-encoded secret key (41 bytes)
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • curvePublic(MemorySegment, MemorySegment)

    • curvePublic

      public static int curvePublic(MemorySegment z85PublicKey, MemorySegment z85SecretKey)
      Derives the public key from a CURVE secret key.

      This function derives the public key from a given CURVE secret key. Both keys are Z85-encoded strings of 40 characters plus null terminator. The public key buffer must be at least 41 bytes.

      This function corresponds to zmq_curve_public() in the C API.

      Parameters:
      z85PublicKey - a pointer to a buffer to store the Z85-encoded public key (41 bytes)
      z85SecretKey - a pointer to the Z85-encoded secret key
      Returns:
      0 on success, -1 on error
      See Also:
      • curveKeypair(MemorySegment, MemorySegment)
